newsitem.title: JAPAN: Minor Metals - Vanadium continues upward march.
newsitem.headline: Minor Metals - Vanadium continues upward march.

text.p: Minor metal markets showed spotty signs of firmness, with molybdenum and especially vanadium continuing to rise, due in part to supply difficulties, Asian traders said on Tuesday.
Worldwide tightness in the vanadium market continued to drive prices higher, Japan traders said, reflecting cuts in raw material supplies from South Africa, Russia and other sources.
"The point is, there's nobody selling it," said one trade house source, who added that the latest quotations from Europe were at $18 a kg for ferrovanadium, with prices seen rising further.
Sentiment was also bullish, though less so, for molybdenum, with trouble at a U.S. supplier expected to continue at least through the first half of this year, traders said.

Song Xiaoying, managing director of Shangxiang Minmetals Ltd, expected molybdenum oxide prices to go to $5 a lb, with Chinese molybdenum oxide now at 4.60-4.80 a lb and ferromolybdenum close to $11.20 a kg.

Song, whose Hong Kong-based company represents producers in China of a wide range of base and minor metals, said supply problems in Western countries, coupled with slowed Chinese output during winter, would keep supply tight in the near term.
Official Chinese molybdenum production figures for 1996 have yet to be released, though Song estimated total output at 38 million pounds, similar to 1995.
One Japanese trader said there were offers at $10 a kg for low quality Chinese ferromolybdenum, but the quality of metal that Japanese users wanted would fetch closer to $12.
In the longer term, however, he said U.S. producers may lift output to cool the market and try to forestall overly volatile price swings.
Chinese magnesium prices were on the rise, one trader said, due to the increase on January 1, 1997 of fees levied on producers and exporters, which added $50 a tonne to prices.

"So producers will get a better price but they will lose market share," he said, adding they were competing not only with the higher quality European product but also with Russian material that was welcomed by U.S. buyers.
Chinese magnesium was being offered FOB at $2,000 to $2,100 per tonne, he said, compared with the FOB Rotterdam price of $3,300 for much higher quality product.
The closure of plants producing less than 1,000 tonnes of magnesium metal a year would bring a significant cut in China's magnesium output for this year, a European trader said.
"Output will fall to 50,000 to 60,000 tonnes, from more than 80,000 last year," he said.
In the antimony market, traders in China and Hong Kong said activity that marked the beginning of the year had waned.
One source with a European trading firm said traders who had bought antimony earlier this month failed to find buyers.

But antimony was keeping one Guangzhou trader busy with spot business. He said he sold 80 tonnes to Japanese customers on Tuesday morning at an FOB price of $2,350 per tonne at the southern Chinese port of Haikou.
"Sourcing is tight so close to Chinese New Year," he said. "But in the short term I don't see any slowdown."
